boardgame.name: España 1936
boardgame.description:
In España 1936 you will experience the famous battles of Jarama, Guadalajara and Ebro, command the International Brigades or the Army of Africa. Can you conquer Madrid and force the Republic to surrender or will you lead the Anarchist forces of Durruti to victory?

The game covers a period rarely seen in computer games and has rich historical detail and historical accuracy. It is the first computer strategy game covering the entire Spanish Civil War. You will face the real dilemmas and challenges of the Republicans or Nationalists during the war. Not only must you recruit and train troops, maneuver them and engage the enemy, but you must also manage your nation’s limited resources.

Using the powerful AGE engine, España: 1936 covers the complete Spanish Civil War from 1936-1939. The game features more than 200 regions, complete with cities, roads, weapons factories, weather types, factions and subfactions of the time of the war. The game includes a grand campaign plus the Fall of the North, a host of historical leaders, units and events. España: 1936 is a must-have for any grand strategy fan.

Designed by Miguel Santacruz from Headquarter S.L.

Headquarter: https://www.hqwargames.com
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/HeadquarterSL/
Twitter: @HEADQUARTERGAM1

Source: The Publisher Website.

boardgame.name: Table Pack 10: Attack From Mars and Genie
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

This pack adds recreations of two pinball tables to Pinball Arcade.

Attack From Mars was released in 1995 by Bally and has an alien invasion theme. The playfield includes a moving flying saucer which must be shot down by the player, after destroying it's force field by hitting the three targets protecting it. The Martians are attacking five famous monuments around the world, including the Eiffel Tower, the Tower of Pisa and the Statue of Liberty. The overall goal is to complete six different objectives, to enable Rule the Universe mode.

Genie was released in 1979 by Gottlieb and features a fantasy 'genie in the bottle' theme with terrific artwork. The table features five flippers on the playfield, including two in the top left which create a mini-playfield. As with many tables of this era, a key way of scoring points is to increase the Bonus and the Multiplier, which are scored when the ball drains. Gaining extra balls allows the Bonus to be scored more times, but on this table it is also possible to score the Bonus earlier by building the Bonus over a certain level and hitting the Kickout Hole in the top right corner.

boardgame.name: Table Pack 11: Dr. Dude and His Excellent Ray and Firepower
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

This pack adds recreations of two pinball tables to Pinball Arcade.

Dr. Dude and His Excellent Ray was released in 1990 by Bally and features a comic book theme. The overall goal is to raise your 'Dudeness Level' from Plain Dude to Super Dude. If you manage this, it unlocks the Gazillion point shot! In order to advance the Dude-O-Meter, the player must activate the multi-ball mode, by collecting three Elements of Coolness - The Gift of Gab, The Heart of Rock 'N Roll and The Magnetic Personality.

Firepower was released in 1980 by Williams and had an outer-space war theme. This was the first solid-state table to include a multi-ball mode and the ability to change the lit lanes for the bonus multiplier, features which became mainstays of later tables. The table is very open, with two sets of three targets the key to the vast majority of the features of the table, including increasing the Bonus and activating the Locks for the multiball mode.

boardgame.name: Table Pack 12: Cactus Canyon and Central Park
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

This pack adds recreations of two pinball tables to Pinball Arcade.

Cactus Canyon was released in 1998 by Bally and has a Western theme. The playfield includes two model pistols, a goldmine and a desperado with a hat which can be shot off! This was the last conventional Bally pinball machine and less than 1000 were produced. The main aim is to activate High Noon mode by completing five tasks as the town Marshall.

Central Park was released in 1966 by Gottlieb and is set in the famous New York park. It features an animated monkey on the backglass which rings a bell for every 100 points scored. As an early table it has just two small flippers with a large gap between them. As such, nudging the table was an essential tactic. The main objective of this game is to increase the yellow and green target score values. This increases the value scored by hitting other targets on the playfield. Increasing the yellow or green targets to the maximum awards a Special (extra ball).

boardgame.name: Table Pack 13: White Water and Space Shuttle
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

This pack adds recreations of two pinball tables to Pinball Arcade.

White Water was released in 1993 by Williams with a white water rafting theme. The aim of the game is to navigate the rapids to reach Wet Willie's River Ranch. This is achieved by hitting various Hazard shots. The table features a whirlpool and even an encounter with Bigfoot!

Space Shuttle was released in 1984 by Williams, and is themed around NASA'a Space Shuttle. The playfield includes a large plastic shuttle, along with Astronauts constructing objects in space. The primary objective of the game is to score the current, randomly selected Shuttle Value, by collecting the letters S-H-U-T-T-L-E. The Shuttle Value can be a simple score, or can include other features such as carrying the Bonus over to the next ball, or lighting an Extra Ball.

boardgame.name: Table Pack 14: Centaur and Pin•Bot
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

This pack adds recreations of two pinball tables to Pinball Arcade.

Centaur was released in 1981 by Bally. It has a fantasy with a highly unusual black and white artwork. The game rewards accuracy through completing targets in specific sequence. A key feature of the game is the multi-ball mode. Completing the O-R-B-S drop-targets in sequence both locks a ball, and immediately launches a ball into the playfield. Balls can be released by hitting a Release target. Up to five balls can be in play at any one time.

Pin•Bot was released in 1986 by Williams and is the first in the Pin•Bot trilogy. The aim is to visit all nine planets of the solar system (Pluto was still a planet at the time!) before eventually reaching the Sun. The table features Pin•Bot's visor, which can be opened to reveal two Eye Eject Holes. Hitting a ball into both Eyes activates a 2-ball Multi-Ball.

boardgame.description:
There is an unusual cabin deep in the woods. It had served as a laboratory and a dwelling for three generations of Lodgers.

But as of late the latest Lodger has been noticing weird changes in familiar surroundings; things are missing, noises and rattle heard. Something odd is coming out of the woods. Come night, it seems like someone's made himself at home in the twilight of rooms, attics, and cellars.

You need to stay awake and sane till dawn.

boardgame.name: The Order: 1886
boardgame.description:
The Order: 1886 is set in an alternate history London, where an old order of knights keep all of the world safe from half breed monsters, who are a combination of animal and man. In the game's history, around the seventh or eighth centuries a small number of humans took on bestial traits. The majority of humans feared these half-breeds and war broke out. Despite the humans outnumbering the half-breeds, their animal strength gave them the upper hand in centuries of conflict.

Centuries earlier, humanity finds new hope in King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table. King Arthur and his like-minded knights take the fight to the half breeds, but Arthur soon realizes it's a losing battle. Through a mysterious turn of fate, the Knights discover Blackwater, a mystical liquid that significantly extends their lifetimes and gives them remarkable healing abilities. Despite this new advantage, the half-breeds continue to win battle after battle, until the Industrial Revolution turns the tide. Engineers are far ahead of their time, inventing technologies such as thermal imaging, Zeppelins, and wireless communications. New weapons belch electricity, ignite clouds of molten metal on top of enemies, and fulfill dual functions as fragmentation grenades and proximity mines.

Source: Wikipedia, "The Order: 1886," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: P.O.N.E. "Protectors of Neo Earth"
boardgame.description:
Neo Realms Entertainment is proud to announce the release of P.O.N.E.

Protectors of Neo-Earth or P.O.N.E. is a tactical board game with deck building properties. Players battle for control over castles that afford them points toward more powerful warrior cards. When battle is joined at a castle, the players choose their battle cards and fight for control over the lands of Neo Earth.

P.O.N.E. has 3 phases of the game & they occur in the following order each round: Payment, Movement & Combat.

- Payment Phase: Players are paid based on the number and types of lands controlled.

- Movement Phase: Each player may move any or all of his pawns one space to an adjacent castle.

- Combat Phase: Combat occurs when one or more pawns challenges another pawn for control of a castle.

The object of the game is to collect the most opposing pawns. The game ends when only 1 color pawn remains.

boardgame.name: World of Warplanes
boardgame.description:
World of Warplanes is the flight combat MMO action game set in the Golden Age of military aviation. The game continues the armored warfare theme marked in the highly-acclaimed World of Tanks and will throw players into a never-ending tussle for air dominance.

Based purely on aircraft setting, World of Warplanes will allow players to build full-scale careers of virtual pilots offering machines of several key eras, staring from 1930’s with biplanes and up to Korean War jet fighters that led the way to modern air forces.

World of Warplanes will feature a wide range of warbirds, each of them unique in their effectiveness and behavior. Virtual pilots will choose from three main warplane classes — single-engine light fighters capable of engaging enemies in close dogfights, heavy fighters with their deadly straight attacks, and ground-attack aircraft, the fearsome threat for ground targets.

Every plane will feature multiple variations of ammo types, engines, and other crucial modules, and their various combinations will allow to pick the optimal configuration for the most effective behavior in combat.

Source: The Developer Website.

boardgame.description:
Dead Man's Draw is a simple and strategic card game of risk and reward for 2 to 4 players. Players take turns drawing cards and combining their special abilities to plunder the most loot without busting their entire hands.

The core of your turn in Dead Man’s Draw is all in the flip: pulling the top card off the deck and using its special ability. Your turn isn’t over until you say it is, though. You can keep pulling cards as long as you like – until you play a card of a suit already seen, at which point you lose everything. Knowing when to stop and "bank" your cards is the biggest decision you make in Dead Man’s Draw, but being too timid lets braver opponents pass you up with bigger, more profitable turns.

The cards’ special abilities are key to success in Dead Man’s Draw, and they build off of each other. Each suit in DMD has an effect that the player can target when they flip a card of that suit.

Anchor – Keep everything you drew before the Anchor even if you bust.

Cannon – Destroy one card an opponent has previously banked.

Chest – Double your haul by banking as many cards directly from the discard pile as are in the river when you bank the Chest – but only if you also bank a Key.

Hook – Play one of your previously banked cards.

Key – Enables the Chest special.

Kraken – Oh no! You’re forced to draw at least two more cards.

Map – Draw three cards from the discard pile and play one.

Mermaid – No ability, but worth more points (Mermaids are numbered 4-9 instead of 2-7).

Oracle – Look at the next card before deciding if you want to play it.

Sword – Steal an opponent’s previously banked card and play it.

Many of these work well together, like using a Hook to re-play a Sword from your hand to steal an opponent’s Chest to go with your Key – racking up huge points by playing abilities well and not solely through the luck of the draw.

As soon as the deck is depleted, players total up the value of the highest card they’ve banked from each suit. High score wins.

boardgame.name: Castles
Dan Zimmer's Castles
boardgame.description:
In the game of CASTLES, two players compete across the gaming table to build a Kingdom of cards.

As each player takes a turn drawing from the deck, you'll seek to gather the support of Dukes, Counts and Barons while also attracting Champions and Wizards to your Court. As you rise in power, your Nobles acquire Lands and Serfs, you'll add a Wife and Heir to your throne and move slowly toward becoming the most powerful Kingdom in the land. But wait... your opponent works to undo all you've built! You face opposition from his Minions, Magick spells and Armies. You are forced to Wage War with your Generals and Arms to seal your legacy in stone.

In the end, only one CASTLE can prevail!

Fast paced and fun, the game is quick to learn but challenging to play. While a session can be over in as little as 30 minutes, aggressive play and thoughtful strategy will keep you on the edge of your seat in game after game!

Players take turns drawing from a deck of 168 cards. As the game progresses, players may decide to try to Block their opponent’s next card draw by using the combined values of either Minions/Magick or Champions/Arms. As players gain more cards in their Kingdom, they may decide to wage war with their Army, attempting to destroy their opponent’s Kingdom while delaying paths to victory.

During the game:
The players will be building their own Kingdoms while attempting to hinder their opponent's progress by waging war or blocking their draws. Striking a balance of building, organizing, blocking and attacking is integral to victory!

During a turn, A player may perform one of five available actions.
1. Draw a card from the deck
2. Wage war against their opponent by combining the strength of their General, Champion and Arms
3. Use a Wizard card's ability
4. Top off a stack (move one card in any stack to the top of the pile)
5. Move the top card in a stack from one column to another, left or right

After completing an action, the player may opt to block their opponent's draw by combining either their Minion/Magick or Champion/Arms values. Three block conditions can occur based on the opponent's card draw value:
1. Lower value than the block total - drawn card is discarded
2. Equal value - both the drawn card and all blocking cards are discarded
3. Higher value - Drawn card is kept. Blocking cards and additional cards (equaling or exceeding the drawn value) are discarded

To Win the Game:
Be the first player to complete their Kingdom, consisting of 18 total cards in a specific arrangement.

boardgame.name: Infraction
boardgame.description:
The year is 2025, and the war on crime is all but lost. The streets are filled with fear as abandoned buildings and darkened alleyways haunt the imaginations of the few innocent citizens brave enough to remain. Gunfire echoes across the cities as gang violence brings vast urban decay. The global war between the Mafia and Triad syndicates has brought civil society to its knees. The fate of the criminal world is to be decided by the force you can muster and economies you can develop in the ultimate crime war that is: INFRACTION.

Game play consists of hiring mercenaries and building developments. Each player is trying to kill the other's boss. Using mercenaries to attack, and developments to gain riches, as well as the odd trick 'o' trade, they try to dominate the board in the hope of wounding the enemy boss. The game starts with each player drawing cards and using a family bank balance as a kickstart to their criminal empire. From here you build your syndicate over the course of the game.

boardgame.name: Heroes of Ahlmeran
boardgame.description:
Heroes of Ahlmeran (HoA) is a cooperative card game where 2 - 5 players come together and build an adventuring party from unique Hero Cards and Feat Cards and then complete Quests to help the land of Ahlmeran. The game requires both team strategy and problem solving abilities.

As the players, you will build your party from a selection of 12 Heroes spanning across 6 Races. The Humans, lost among the land now, with no real home. The Dwarves, at home among the rock with their advanced technology. Elves, Cast out by their past mistake, they are no longer rulers of the land but rather 2nd class citizens. The Canin, a proud race resembling a blue wolf. The Puar, the cat people of Guuman. And then the Gnomes. No one knows magic more intimately.

From those races you will select of the 6 Classes that best suits your play style. Artificer, master of artifacts and arcane knowledge. Barbarian, nomad tribes bestowing their nature knowledge and sheer might to the people. Elemental Mage, master of the 4 elements. Priest, Master of the holy arts, both offensive and defensive. Ranger, commander of nature and all that resides within her. And Templar, defender of the people, master of arcane. Each of the classes come with bonuses and a unique 40 card deck that your character will use.

Then, you select a Location Deck to play with, a deck of 15 cards to represent where your quest takes place.

Finally, you pick a Quest Deck, the enemy or circumstance your heroes are struggling against. It could be anything from breaking a curse, thwarting a thief to facing a brutal goblin ambush!

Over the course of the game, you will play cards from your Class Deck, working together with your friends to complete whatever the Quest Deck requires for your victory.

With each Quest Deck completed and Location Deck explored, you gain the chance to accumulate more rare items, allowing you to play the game countless times with more combinations than we can count

boardgame.name: A Thousand Leaves
boardgame.description:
A mythico-historical card game based on 1000 cards that weave an edutaining spell through the looking glass of time.

This is a game of history, drama and mystery made from 1000 unique Cards, each inspired by special parts of history. It may be played by 2 people, although the game is ideally played with 4-6 participants. The title evokes the oldest known Japanese poetry anthology, Ten Thousand Leaves, which transferred many oral poetry traditions to paper for the first time in the 8th Century. A Thousand Leaves is also a translation of “Chiba”, a region in Japan.

Every player is a Leader of one of the 8 Realms. The game takes place in Turns, each of which consists of 4 PHASES: Diplomatic, Military, Society and Spirit. In each Phase, each player may take one free Action (“Phase Action”). Armies may traverse the globe or Priests build Temples, units turn against their masters or debates alter the fate of nations.

The game also features a representation of ancient warfare, complete with a Center, Left and Right and real battlefield strategies. Each player takes an action through pieces (Face Cards) on an imaginary board, alternating until all pieces have taken at least one action before the next turn begins.

boardgame.name: Sticks and Stones
boardgame.description:
Sticks and Stones is a fun, strategic card game, that gives you the power to choose your path to victory.

In S&S you will:

-Battle your opponent through the use of characters, enhancements, vehicles, heroes, and creatures!

-Beef up your characters with potions, special abilities, magic, and more!

-Crush your enemy using brute force, or a more tactical approach!

S&S has:

-Unique, and crazy cool artwork!

-Custom die for tracking progress!

-High quality components made to last through years of fun!

-An easy learning curve, while also giving you the option for more in depth gameplay!

How is it played?

1. Build your deck from a large selection of cool characters, crazy enhancements, and awesome creatures. Then choose your hero for the battle!

2. Obliterate your opponent! Using your deck you will Deploy>Enhance>Attack>Discard. Use ranged and melee cards to attack. Juice them up with some spells. Place in some defensive vehicles to block incoming attacks. Use counter-attack cards to send the enemies attacks right back at them!

3. After capturing the opposing hero, regroup and rebuild your deck for the next battle. Don't forget to adjust your strategy, because now your opponent will gain an advantage through the use of terrain cards! So stay alert and think outside of the box or you might be caught blindsided by a brutal attack

boardgame.name: Path of Dice
boardgame.description:
In Path of Dice the goal is to create a connected path of dice from your starting area to the opposite end of the board by placing the just-rolled dice according to a few simple rules. Your opponent is of course doing the same from the other end thus creating a lot of conflict.

It's a fun, fast, simple and surprisingly strategic game for two or four players.

A 2-player game is played in about ten minutes with strategic decisions being made on most throws.

With so many dice being rolled luck does play a big part in who wins the game. But the strategic depth of the game could still surprise its creator even after 50+ played games.

boardgame.name: Table Pack 15: The Champion Pub and Whirlwind
boardgame.description:
User Summary:

This pack adds recreations of two pinball tables to Pinball Arcade.

The Champion Pub was released in 1998 by Bally. It is set in a backstreet pub playing host to a boxing ring. The theme is around training your boxer, earning jewels on your belt, defeating opponents in the ring, and aiming to win the Pub Championship. You train by completing tasks such as the jump rope, the speed bag and the heavy bag. When having reached a high-enough life level from training, the Heavy Bag rotates to reveal the head of your opponent. Defeating the opponent is achieved by hitting him in the body, or by launching off ramps to hit him in the head until his life is reduced to zero. Other hits can be achieved by scoring combos off the various ramps.

Whirlwind was released in 1990 by Williams and is themed around storm-chasers. The original table included a fan which blowed in the player's face when the storm starts picking up. The playfield includes three rotating discs, which can throw the ball in unexpected directions, and six jet bumpers, which also add a high degree of randomness - perfectly complementing the theme of the table. The primary aim of the game is to activate Feel The Power Multiball by locking two balls. In order to activate the locks, various storm and navigation themed activities need to be completed.

“There are only five of us now, three of us didn’t make it when we ran into them on the other side of the stream. None of us wants to think that they are following us, mindless, only wanting to feast on our flesh, but we cannot stop thinking of the horror behind us.
We are all shocked and exhausted but we must keep going. The trees are thinning out and I can see lights ahead… we’ve almost made it… A farm surrounded by bushes but with lights on, there must be other survivors there. No, not bushes – the house is surrounded by dozens of zombies, trying to break in. I can hear their moans even this far away, they sound so close.
They are among the trees. Shambling over dead wood, we are surrounded…”

7ombieTV is a standalone Zombie horror spinoff from acclaimed spy-fi miniatures game 7TV. It is the 1980s, and the dead have risen with terrifying amounts of gore and a fearsome appetite for your flesh! Only with a bold heart and a large amount of unlikely weaponry can you survive the night…

Players make their force spending points and following rules on the number of heroes and sheep they can have as there are three levels of characters. The game is won when one side completes the objective, points can be scored for other task completed during the game such as killing of zombies! Elements can be used in the 7TV games if desired.

boardgame.name: The World Beneath the Clouds
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

How great would be the desire in every admirer of nature be to view, if such were possible, the scenery of another planet? Charles Darwin

Venus in 1883 has much to admire, and much to fear as well. Explorers of that world would be well advised to read this volume. In it they will find the details of climate, culture and creatures of that mysterious planet. Prepare yourself for a voyage through airless space aboard a Ewing and Stuart powered liner. make landfall by gliding down to the salt flats of Equatoria. Outfit your party in the shops of the International City. Learn of the deadly Sea Kings and the even more dangerous seas upon which they sail. Barter with the most greedy merchants in the solar system, the Naxlii, or explore the cloud forests with warriors of the Cloud Kingdoms.

This source book for Stars of Empire will give game masters and players enough material for numberless adventures or campaigns. New rules cover the differences between characters raised on Earth and those born on Venus. Some of the deadliest creatures of Venus are described and the ecology of the world is well documented. This source book can be used for any campaign thats seeks a well detailed and unique setting for planetary adventures.

boardgame.name: Prowlers & Paragons Superhero Roleplaying Game
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:



Welcome to Prowlers & Paragons!

Prowlers & Paragons (or P&P) is a tabletop roleplaying game with a narration-driven, rules-light system designed to emulate four-color superhero comics. Let’s break that down so you can see what you’re getting yourself into.

P&P is a tabletop roleplaying game. We’re going to assume you’ve got this one covered.

P&P is a narration-driven system. The rules in this game are not effects driven. For the most part, they don’t tell you what happens. Instead, they tell you who gets to describe what happens. And that’s what it’s all about in P&P: describing what happens. Both the players and the gamemaster (GM) take turns narrating events in the game world. This makes P&P feel more like an exercise in collaborative storytelling than a typical roleplaying game. However, P&P isn’t totally freeform and open-ended either. There are rules that help determine what characters can do and how they compare to one another, especially in combat! This prevents the game from devolving into a never-ending debate about what is and isn’t reasonable.

P&P is rules light. It’s chock full of gross oversimplifications and blatant inaccuracies that mimic comic book tropes rather than real-world facts. This also makes P&P a simple game with a streamlined set of rules. Once you know what you’re doing, you should be able to play without ever opening the book.

Finally, P&P is designed to emulate four-color superhero comics. This game is about the heroic things the characters do and the heroic burdens they shoulder. Mundane matters get little attention. There aren’t any detailed rules for dealing with money and wealth, but there most definitely is a rule for smashing into a bank vault. Let’s be perfectly clear: This is not a deep and cerebral game. P&P was designed to let you play stories about super heroes who save the world and beat the snot out of villains who richly deserve it. Like so much of the genre, P&P is a gleefully unapologetic exercise in heroic wish fulfillment.



Core Rules!

The core rules are finally here!

Included here are 2 versions of the game, one in full beautiful color and one with crisp, black-and-white line art so that your printer won't break up with you for printing it out. Both are 142 pages long and include:

Chapter 1: Introduction: Um ... it's an introduction. What did you expect?

Chapter 2: Action: This chapter include most of the rules you need to play the game, including rules for narrative task resolution and comic book slugfests!

Chapter 3: Characters: Here is where you learn how to make heroes! We have full character creation rules that allow you to create street level prowlers, cosmic paragons, and everything in between.

Chapter 4: Heroism: This chapter explains the use of Resolve and Adversity, the narrative currency that players and gamemasters use to bend the rules of the game and even the game world itself in their favor.

Chapter 5: Wonderful Toys: You like gear? Then this is the chapter for you. This chapter includes weapons, armor, miscellaneous equipment, vehicles (and yes, vehicle combat rules), and even rules for creating your own makeshift items on the fly in the middle of a story. What could possibly go wrong?

Chapter 6: Big Bad World: It's a big world full of bad stuff that give heroes headaches. Disasters, Diseases, Hazards ... ther're all in here.

Chapter 7: Friends & Foes: A veritable rogues gallery at your disposal. A host of mundane (and not so mundane) npcs, from Athletes to Zombies, a large number of animals from Bats to Zebras (yes, of course there are dinosaurs in there), and a collection of archetypal supers from the Acrobat to the Weather Controller that you can used as villains, or even as heroes if you're in a rush.

Chapter 8: Playing the Game: This chapter provides both players and gamemasters (but mostly gamemasters) with tools, tips, and tricks for running the best super hero roleplaying game they can run. We give you our thoughts about playing and running roleplaying games while desperately trying not to sound patronizing.

Chapter 9: From the Ashes: A light-hearted (and rather forgiving) introductory adventurefor a group of heroes of standard power level.



The world needs heroes.



Take a Stand! Join the Fight!



BE A HERO!
